rev.diff:
Line 2: Line 2:
Unlike Blue Frog, Okopipi sought to use a [[Distributed computing|distributed]] model in order to avoid any [[single point of failure]]. It was planned to be based on a P2P network nicknamed "the frognet". On failure to connect it was planned to still opt-out given e-mail addresses. The project is perpetually in the design phase. It was being specifically engineered to prevent the DDoS accusations levelled against its progenitors. Its peer-to-peer nature is unusual amongst anti-spam solutions, with no other peer-to-peer opt-out solutions of note available.
Unlike Blue Frog, Okopipi sought to use a [[Distributed computing|distributed]] model in order to avoid any [[single point of failure]]. It was planned to be based on a P2P network nicknamed "the frognet". On failure to connect it was planned to still opt-out given e-mail addresses. The project is perpetually in the design phase. It was being specifically engineered to prevent the DDoS accusations levelled against its progenitors. Its peer-to-peer nature is unusual amongst anti-spam solutions, with no other peer-to-peer opt-out solutions of note available.
  +   +
==Current state==
  +
The project is considered to be dead, and the official website has not been updated since 2006 [http://www.okopipi.org]
